Scope and form:
This course is designed for master students with engineering education background,
particular for automation, robotics and autonomous system students who has a special interest in the subjects of safety and reliability. There will be 10 lectures, including several guest lectures from the industry. Students will be evaluated based on a report of a 3-weeks final project.
Academic prerequisites: None, but general engineering background in automation or robotics is recommended.
Course co-responsible: Jing Wu (Primary contact person) , Lyngby Campus, Building 326 , jinwu@dtu.dk
Department: 34 Department of Electrical and Photonics Engineering
General course objectives:
General course objectives
The objective of the course is to teach students systematic methods and tools for identifying, analyzing and managing reliability and safety issues in automation and robotic systems. These are useful to prepare students to solve new safety problems and uptake of the legal, societal and ethical aspects in the era of industry 4.0.
Learning objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
Define safety and reliability in relation with robotic and automation systems.
Describe fundamental safety concepts and theories in relation with robotic and automation systems.
Describe ethical aspects from the human-machine (robotics) perspective.
Explain what is standard, and what is CE marking.
Identify what are the relevant standards and required procedures.
Identify causing factors that contribute to the accidents in relation with robotic and automation systems by using accident-causing theories.
Perform system safety analysis using safety analysis methods by following the safety analysis procedure for robotic and automation systems.
Perform reliability analysis of robotic and automation systems for simple events using reliability analysis methods.
Perform risk assessment according to ISO12100.
Write sections of a risk assessment report.
